{{Infobox Civil Conflict | title = 2010 G20 Toronto summit riots | partof = the [[anti-globalization movement]] | image = [[File:G-20 Toronto June 2010 (27).jpg|220px]] | caption = Riot control emerge as a police car burns in the background in [[Toronto]] on 26 June | place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | date = June 18–28, 2010 | status = | goals = | methods = [[Political rally|rally]], [[Demonstration (people)|demonstration]], [[riot]]ing, [[vandalism]] | injuries = 39 reported injuries during arrests. A total of 97 police officers received injuries during the G20. An unknown number of protesters who were not arrested sustained injuries. | fatalities = }} Public protesting and demonstrations began one week ahead of the [[2010 G20 Toronto summit]], which took place in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada on 26−27 June. The protests were for various causes, including poverty and anti-capitalism.
Protests mainly consisted of peaceful [[demonstration (people)|demonstration]]s and [[Political rally|rallies]] but also took form of a [[riot]] as a group of protesters using [[black bloc]] tactics caused [[vandalism]] to several businesses in [[Downtown Toronto]]. More than 20,000 police, military, and security personnel were involved in policing the protests, which at its largest numbered 10,000 protesters.<ref>CTV News. "Police take 'pre-emptive strikes' with sweeping arrests." (27 Jun 2010) http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100627/more_arrests_toronto_100627/20100627/?hub=TorontoNewHome</ref><ref>Office of the Auditor General of Canada. "Chapter 1—Expenditures for the 2010 G8 and G20 Summits." 2011 Spring Report of the Auditor General of Canada. http://www.oag-bvg.gc.ca/internet/English/parl_oag_201104_01_e_35220.html</ref> While there were no deaths, 97 officers and 39 arrestees were injured, and at least 40 shops were vandalised, constituting at least [[Canadian dollar|C$]]750,000 worth of damage.<ref>David Ridder and Susan Delacourt. {{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/829912--pressure-builds-on-ottawa-for-compensation?bn=1 |title=Pressure builds on Ottawa for compensation |publisher=''Toronto Star'' (Canada) |date= June 29, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-28 | first1=David | last1=Rider | first2=Susan | last2=Delacourt}}</ref><ref name=globemailjuly2011>{{cite news|title=Toronto police were overwhelmed at G20, review reveals|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/toronto-police-were-overwhelmed-at-g20-review-reveals/article2073215/|accessdate=24 June 2011|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=23 June 2011|first=Adrian|last=Morrow| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110624112511/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/toronto-police-were-overwhelmed-at-g20-review-reveals/article2073215/| archivedate= 24 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Over 1000 arrests were made, making it the largest [[mass arrest]] in Canadian history.<ref name=globemailjuly2011>{{cite news|title=Toronto police were overwhelmed at G20, review reveals|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/toronto-police-were-overwhelmed-at-g20-review-reveals/article2073215/|accessdate=24 June 2011|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=23 June 2011|first=Adrian|last=Morrow| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110624112511/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/toronto-police-were-overwhelmed-at-g20-review-reveals/article2073215/| archivedate= 24 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In the aftermath of the protests, the [[Toronto Police Service]] and the [[Integrated Security Unit]] (ISU) of the G20 Toronto summit were heavily criticized for brutality during the arrests and eventually went under public scrutiny by media and human rights activists. There has been legal action in the form of a class action lawsuit towards the Toronto police on behalf of all whom were arrested despite the Toronto Police's several attempts to stop court proceedings by appealing the case. As of November 10, 2016 The Supreme Court of Canada ruled that it will not hear the Toronto Police Services Board's appeal and court proceedings may go on.
==Preliminary events==
===Early opposition=== A [[Royal Bank of Canada]] branch in [[Ottawa]] was [[Firebombing|firebombed]] just before dawn on May 18, 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2010/05/18/ott-glebe-bank-fire.html |title=CBC News – Ottawa – RBC firebombed as protest, group claims |publisher=CBC.ca |date=2010-05-18 |accessdate=2010-06-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100522013917/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2010/05/18/ott-glebe-bank-fire.html| archivedate= 22 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The attackers posted video on [[YouTube]] showing a large fireball igniting inside the bank. The video then listed the [[manifesto]] of a previously unknown group calling itself the FFFC. The message stated that the attack against the bank was because of the growing suffering of Vancouver's poor in the shadow of RBC's major sponsorship of the [[2010 Vancouver Olympics]] and [[2010 Winter Paralympics|Paralympics]] in [[Vancouver]] and [[Whistler, British Columbia]] and claimed these events were held "on stolen [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] land."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fiImoI0JdPQ YouTube Video] of bank firebombing of Royal Bank Branch, Ottawa, Ontario</ref> In addition to social issues and [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|aboriginal]] land claims, the video claimed the actions were sparked by environmental and [[deforestation]] related concerns surrounding the [[Athabasca oil sands|Alberta tar sands]] projects in ''"Canada's"'' prairies, in which the video claims RBC is substantially involved and which G8/G20 decisions furthered.<ref name="CTVCharged">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20100519/anarchists-firebomb-bank-100519/20100519?hub= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524131549/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20100519/anarchists-firebomb-bank-100519/20100519?hub= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-05-24 |title=Terrorism charges possible in bank firebombing: police – CTV News |publisher=Ctv.ca |date=2010-05-19 |accessdate=2010-06-04 |df= }}</ref> The attackers also stated their intention to be present during the [[36th G8 summit|G8]] and the G20 Toronto summits the following month.<ref name="TSun1">{{cite web|last=Jackson |first=Kenneth |url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/canada/2010/05/19/14005326.html |title=Anarchy among anarchists after firebomb | Canada | News |publisher=Toronto Sun |date=2010-05-19 |accessdate=2010-06-04}}</ref> The projected recurrence of such acts of violence and the escalating [[rhetoric]] of anti-summit protest plans caused the G8/G20 [[Integrated Security Unit]] (ISU) to increase its security measures.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/812976--ottawa-firebombing-proves-security-need-clement-says |title=Ottawa firebombing proves security need, Clement says |publisher=thestar.com |date=2010-05-21 |accessdate=2010-06-04 | location=Toronto | first=Gail | last=Swainson}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2010/05/22/wanted-500-extra-police-for-g20-summit/ |title=Wanted: 500 extra police for G20 summit | Posted Toronto | National Post |publisher=News.nationalpost.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-04}}</ref> The attacks were quickly and widely criticized by the media, politicians, and other protest groups<ref>{{cite web|author=QMI Agency |url=http://www.torontosun.com/comment/editorial/2010/05/19/14012571.html |title=Brainless thugs all about mayhem | Editorial | Comment |publisher=Toronto Sun |date= |accessdate=2010-06-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistproject.ca/bullet/358.php |title=Socialist Project | The Bullet |publisher=Socialistproject.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-06-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100527064005/http://www.socialistproject.ca/bullet/358.php| archivedate= 27 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Three suspects were arrested on June 19, 2010; with one, Roger Clement, being convicted in December 2010 while charges against the other two were stayed for lack of evidence. Clement, a 58-year-old retired federal government employee, formerly working for the Canadian International Development Agency, eventually received a 3½ year prison sentence, that included 6 months for vandalism of another RBC branch in February 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/news/national/article/103466--man-who-firebombed-bank-gets-three-year-sentence |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120723071425/http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/news/national/article/103466--man-who-firebombed-bank-gets-three-year-sentence |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-23 |title=Man Who Firebombed Bank Gets Three-Year Sentence |publisher=CityTV |date=2010-12-07 |accessdate=2011-07-31 }}</ref>
Initial estimates of the damage, immediately following the attack, set the price-tag at around $300,000 and projected that the bank would be closed for several weeks. At the time of Clement's trial, reports stated that the branch was closed for months with total costs of $1,600,000.<ref name="CTVCharged" /><ref name="TSun1" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20101207/bank-fire-bomber-sentence-101207/ |title=Man who firebombed bank sentenced to 3 years |publisher=CTV News |date=2010-12-07 |accessdate=2011-07-31}}</ref>
An individual was arrested for vandalism on May 28, after being caught spray-painting anti–G20 slogans on windows and [[automated teller machine]]s in Downtown Toronto.<ref>{{cite web|author=QMI Agency |url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/canada/2010/05/28/14168296.html |title=Anti-G20 slogans spray-painted on T.O. banks | Canada | News |publisher=Toronto Sun |date=2010-05-28 |accessdate=2010-06-04}}</ref> Two individuals were arrested in [[London, Ontario]] after attaching posters to public property encouraging disruption of the G20 summit and canvassing protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Canada/2010/06/17/14420391.html |title=G20 activists jailed for poster – Canada – Canoe.ca |publisher=Cnews.canoe.ca |date=2008-07-22 |accessdate=2010-06-20}}</ref>
Key groups which organized early in opposition to the summit included [[Canadian Labour Congress]], [[Council of Canadians]], [[Greenpeace]], [[Ontario Coalition Against Poverty]], [[Ontario Federation of Labour]], [[Oxfam]] and the Toronto Community Mobilization Network.<ref>Sheila Whyte. [http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/06/04/f-g8-g20-protesters.html "The Protesters: Who's who at the summits,"] CBC News. June 9, 2010.</ref>
===Week prior to summit=== [[File:G-20 Toronto June 2010 (2).jpg|left|thumb|An early demonstration on [[Yonge Street]] on June 24 demanding respect of First Nations treaty rights]] A small rally was conducted on June 17 in the [[Financial District, Toronto|Financial District]] by [[Oxfam Canada]], urging Canada to end [[fossil fuel]] subsidization and take action on world [[poverty]]. The rally also spoofed the summit's high security cost.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE65E4RB20100617?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=Toronto G20 protest hints at more to come | Top News | Reuters |publisher=Ca.reuters.com |date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2010-06-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100622091653/http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE65E4RB20100617?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0| archivedate= 22 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
An anti-poverty protest occurred on June 21, causing traffic congestion.<ref name=toronto1>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100621/lcbo_shut_down_100621/20100621/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto – Police ride herd as G20 protesters march the streets – CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2010-06-22| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100624024104/http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100621/lcbo_shut_down_100621/20100621/?hub=TorontoNewHome| archivedate= 24 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> About 100 protesters marched from [[Allan Gardens]] on [[Sherbourne Street, Toronto|Sherbourne Street]] and continued on [[Yonge Street]], [[Dundas Street (Ontario)|Dundas Street]], and Isabella Street. Police officers on bicycles and military helicopters patrolled the protest; one arrest was made.<ref name=toronto1 /> A few protesters also attempted to occupy an [[Esso]] [[Filling station|gas station]], claiming corporations like Esso "have caused irreparable damage all over the world."<ref name=thestar4>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/826478--g20-protesters-try-to-take-over-downtown-property?bn=1 |title=G20 protesters try to take over downtown property |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-21|accessdate=2010-06-22 | location=Toronto | first=Jayme | last=Poisson| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100625043412/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/826478--g20-protesters-try-to-take-over-downtown-property?bn=1| archivedate= 25 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Other protester concerns were the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]], [[capitalism]], and the G8 and G20 summits.<ref name=toronto1 /> The protest was led by a [[Guelph]]-based group called Sense of Security, an anti-poverty group that was also supported by the [[Ontario Coalition Against Poverty]].<ref name=thestar4 />
The following day, about 200 people from Toronto's [[gay community]] marched through downtown attempting to raise awareness on [[LGBT rights in Canada|homosexual rights]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/827058--gays-lesbians-hold-g20-kiss-in?bn=1 |title=G20 turning downtown Toronto into a ghost town |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-22|accessdate=2010-06-24 | first1=Jennifer | last1=Yang | first2=Liam | last2=Casey| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100626093646/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/827058--gays-lesbians-hold-g20-kiss-in?bn=1| archivedate= 26 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Protesters chanted, "We're queer, we're fabulous, we're against the G20."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2216509620100622 |title=Gay rights protest hits Toronto ahead of G20 |publisher=Reuters |date= 2010-06-22|accessdate=2010-06-24 | first=Pav | last=Jordan| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100626103252/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2216509620100622| archivedate= 26 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] (CBC) labelled the protests as "peaceful" overall.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/22/g20-tuesdayprotestors.html |title=CBC News – Toronto – Protests continue in Toronto as G20 nears |publisher=Cbc.ca |date= 2010-06-22|accessdate=2010-06-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100625060457/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/22/g20-tuesdayprotestors.html| archivedate= 25 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The first sizable G20 protest, of about 1000 people, took place on June 24 with [[First Nations]] groups and supporters from across Canada demanding respect for [[treaty rights]] from the government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/827924--first-nations-demonstrators-take-over-downtown-streets?bn=1 |title=First nations demonstrators take over downtown streets |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-24|accessdate=2010-06-24 | location=Toronto | first=Peter | last=Edwards| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100627143516/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/827924--first-nations-demonstrators-take-over-downtown-streets?bn=1| archivedate= 27 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Demonstrations moved from [[Queen's Park (Toronto)|Queen's Park]] to the [[Toronto Eaton Centre]] along [[University Avenue (Toronto)|University Avenue]] and [[Queen Street West]]. Concerns of protesters were Canada's failure to sign the [[United Nations]]' [[Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples]] and the fact that no aboriginal chiefs were invited to the summits.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/827924--canada-flunks-on-indigenous-rights-protesters-say?bn=1 |title=Canada flunks on indigenous rights, protesters say |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-24|accessdate=2010-06-24 | location=Toronto | first=Peter | last=Edwards}}</ref>
Also on June 24, activist [[Jaggi Singh (activist)|Jaggi Singh]], spokesperson for the group No One Is Illegal, suggested in a news conference that some protesters intended to attempt to breach the security fence in the coming days.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/24/g20-aboriginal.html--first-nations-demonstrators-take-over-downtown-streets?bn=1 |title=First Nations' G20 protest peaceful |publisher=thestar.com |date=2010-06-24 |accessdate=2010-07-10 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
A larger protest was scheduled for June 25 in Toronto, the day the [[36th G8 summit]] began in [[Huntsville, Ontario]].<ref>Hassan, Syed. [http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=19371 "Toronto’s Communities Prepare for the G8 and G20 Summits,"] Centre for Research on Globalization. May 27, 2010.</ref> Protesters attempted to enter the security zone, but were later forced to return by police officers. By evening, protesters set up a tent city at Allan Gardens and stayed overnight to resume protests the following day, the opening of the G20 summit.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/25/g20-protest-friday.html |title=CBC News – Toronto – G20 protesters set up Toronto camp |publisher=Cbc.ca |date= 2010-06-26|accessdate=2010-06-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100627173208/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/25/g20-protest-friday.html| archivedate= 27 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==During the summit==
===June 26: Riots and vandalism=== [[File:G-20 Toronto June 2010 (28).jpg|thumb|right|A rioter on top of a [[Toronto Police Service]] cruiser in flames]] As the G20 leaders arrived in Toronto after the G8 summit in [[Huntsville, Ontario]] wrapped up, a large group comprising as many as 10,000 people protested downtown during the afternoon of June 26.<ref name="CBCprotests">{{cite news|title=G20 protest turns violent|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/06/26/g20-saturday-protests.html|accessdate=26 June 2010|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=June 26, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628031322/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/06/26/g20-saturday-protests.html| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> At the protest, Jeff Atkinson, spokesperson for the [[Canadian Labour Congress]], said, "We don't want G20 countries to cut stimulus spending until jobs recover." [[Greenpeace International]] director [[Kumi Naidoo]] reasoned that "if G20 governments could spend billions of dollars to rescue banks in trouble, why not find money to help unemployed workers for the environment and for social causes." Sid Ryan of the [[Ontario Federation of Labour]] said in a speech, "It wasn't the workers of the world that caused the financial crisis. We don't want to see a transfer of wealth from the public sector to the private sector."<ref>France 24, "Massive Rally Calls on G20 to Put People Ahead of Banks," http://www.france24.com/en/20100626-massive-rally-calls-g20-put-people-ahead-banks{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
According to eyewitness accounts, about 200 marchers broke away from the protest route on Queen Street and headed south on Bay Street towards the convention centre, through [[Financial District, Toronto|Financial District]]. The media would describe the break-off as led by the [[black bloc]], with demonstrators covering their bodies and faces in black clothes. Individuals using the same black bloc tactics have been suspected of being responsible for confrontations in other international summit protests.<ref>{{cite news|author=The Canadian Press |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829168--violent-black-bloc-tactics-on-display-at-g20-protest?bn=1 |title=Violent Black Bloc tactics on display at G20 protest |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-26|accessdate=2010-06-27 | location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630071652/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829168--violent-black-bloc-tactics-on-display-at-g20-protest?bn=1| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Protesters dispersed to damage buildings and vehicles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/g8-g20-black-bloc-100626/20100626?hub=Toronto |title=CTV Toronto - 'Black Bloc' vandal take over Toronto streets - CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100629065237/http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/g8-g20-black-bloc-100626/20100626?hub=Toronto| archivedate= 29 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The intent as interpreted by some media was to distract police forces from the security zone so that other protesters could break in, but police maintained their blockades, protecting the fence.<ref>{{cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/06/27/canada.g20.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&fbid=mZjulc3NxV6 |title=G-20 protests plagued by violence, vandalism - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date= 2010-06-28|accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref> Vandals smashed the windows of various office buildings and stores along [[Yonge Street]], [[Queen Street West]] and [[College Street (Toronto)|College Street]] using hammers, flag poles, umbrellas, chunks of pavement and mailboxes.<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web|author=CBC.ca |url=http://news.ca.msn.com/canada/cbc-article.aspx?cp-documentid=24700313 |title=G20 protest brings violence, arrests - News - MSN CA |publisher=News.ca.msn.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100629073427/http://news.ca.msn.com/canada/cbc-article.aspx?cp-documentid=24700313| archivedate= 29 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Conflicts also erupted between purported anarchists and journalists who were recording property destruction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20100626/summit-protests-100626/ |title=Police attempt to clear crowds amid G20 unrest - CTV News |publisher=Ctv.ca |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630162453/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20100626/summit-protests-100626/| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> After a few hours, many black bloc demonstrators changed into civilian clothes and dissolved into the larger crowd as security forces began to increase in presence. Police later maintained that some protest organizers were complicit in providing cover for the vandals.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/news/local/article/80159--police-display-weapons-seized-during-g20-accuse-activist-network-of-complicity-in-summit-related-violence| title= Police Display Weapons Seized During G20, Accuse Activist Network Of Complicity In Summit-Related Violence| accessdate= 1 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100702004415/http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/news/local/article/80159--police-display-weapons-seized-during-g20-accuse-activist-network-of-complicity-in-summit-related-violence| archivedate= 2010-07-02| deadurl= yes| df= }}</ref>
[[File:G-20 Toronto June 2010 (15).jpg|thumb|left|This [[Starbucks]] branch was one of many shops to have damaged exteriors from the riots]] The first property reportedly damaged was a [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] clothes store. [[Toronto Police Headquarters]] was also damaged.<ref>{{cite news|author=Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/blog-local-view/police-union-chief-sees-very-long-night-ahead/article1619914/ |title=Police union chief sees 'very long night' ahead |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=2010-06-22 |accessdate=2010-06-27 |location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100629193504/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/blog-local-view/police-union-chief-sees-very-long-night-ahead/article1619914/| archivedate= 29 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Media vehicles of the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] and [[CTV Television Network]] were damaged and four [[Toronto Police Service]] cruisers were smashed and set ablaze in various locations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/summit-protests-100626/20100626/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto - Police attempt to clear crowds amid G20 unrest - CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628062552/http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/summit-protests-100626/20100626/?hub=TorontoNewHome| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> American corporations, such as [[Starbucks]], appeared to be the targets of vandalism.<ref name=autogenerated3/> Other targets were [[Foot Locker]], [[Sears Canada|Sears]], [[McDonald's Canada|McDonald's]], [[Tim Hortons]], [[Urban Outfitters]], [[Pizza Pizza]], [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]], [[Swiss Chalet]], and the Zanzibar Tavern, a local strip club whose owner had invited leaders to try G-strings instead of the G20 summit.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref>http://www.torontosun.com/news/g20/2010/06/18/14441556.html A different kind of G summit</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.martiniboys.com/Montreal/article/Violence,%20confrontations%20mar%20G20%20protest-14321.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725044823/http://www.martiniboys.com/Montreal/article/Violence%2C%20confrontations%20mar%20G20%20protest-14321.html |archivedate=2010-07-25 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/more-than-400-arrests-after-violent-protests-2012294.html |title=More than 400 arrests after violent protests - World Politics, World |publisher=The Independent |date= 2010-06-28|accessdate=2010-06-29 | location=London | first=David | last=Usborne| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100629171721/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/more-than-400-arrests-after-violent-protests-2012294.html| archivedate= 29 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> An [[American Apparel]] store was damaged; the [[mannequin]]s on display were taken out and used to further damage nearby stores.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Branches of [[Scotiabank]], [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce]] (CIBC), and [[Toronto-Dominion Bank|TD Bank]] were also damaged. Toronto Police Headquarters, [[Toronto Eaton Centre]], [[Sheraton Centre (Toronto)|Sheraton Centre]], [[Chelsea Hotel, Toronto|Delta Chelsea]] and some buildings in [[Yonge-Dundas Square]] were put in [[lockdown]] mode.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/293894 |title=Toronto G20 protest turns violent, city venues in lockdown |publisher=Digitaljournal.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628144955/http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/293894| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Hospitals along [[University Avenue (Toronto)|University Avenue]], which includes [[Mount Sinai Hospital, Toronto|Mount Sinai]], [[Toronto General Hospital|Toronto General]], [[Princess Margaret Hospital (Toronto)|Princess Margaret]], and [[The Hospital for Sick Children]], were put into [[lockdown]] mode by police.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/24/g20-hospitals.html "Hospitals prepare for G20 casualties,"] CBC News. June 24, 2010; excerpt, hospitals "''...ready to handle any emergencies resulting from downtown protests during the G20 summit;''" tents were erected outside the entrances of downtown hospitals; decontamination stations set up to treat people affected by pepper spray, tear gas, etc.''</ref> [[Toronto Transit Commission]] (TTC) bus and streetcar routes were halted in Downtown, as well as subway service between [[Bloor-Yonge (TTC)|Bloor-Yonge]] and [[St. George (TTC)|St. George]] stations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/toronto-chaos-100626/20100626/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto - TTC lines, Eaton Centre locked down as protests heat up - CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630151222/http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100626/toronto-chaos-100626/20100626/?hub=TorontoNewHome| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[GO Transit]] was requested by the ISU to reroute trains away from [[Union Station (Toronto)|Union Station]], and used [[Danforth GO Station|Danforth]] and [[Exhibition GO Station|Exhibition]] stations as the termini for westbound and eastbound trains respectively,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2010/06/26/g20-protests-shut-down-ttc-hospitals-downtown/ |title=G20: Protests shut down TTC, hospitals downtown | Posted Toronto | National Post |publisher=News.nationalpost.com |date=2010-05-27 |accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref> but free shuttle bus service was made available to passengers from those stations. The TTC also provided free shuttle bus services.<ref>{{cite news|author=Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/ttc-go-transit-offering-free-shuttles-around-downtown-outskirts/article1619716/ |title=TTC, GO Transit offering free shuttles around downtown outskirts |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date= 2010-06-26|accessdate=2010-06-27 |location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630103509/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/ttc-go-transit-offering-free-shuttles-around-downtown-outskirts/article1619716/| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The escalating violence caused Dutch violinist [[André Rieu]] to cancel his concert at the [[Air Canada Centre]] at the last minute.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/article/829113--andre-rieu-concert-at-acc-postponed?bn=1 |title=Andre Rieu concert at ACC postponed |publisher=thestar.com |date=2010-06-11 |accessdate=2010-06-27 | location=Toronto}}</ref>
Sound cannons were not used during the weekend, but [[tear gas]] was used for the first time in the [[history of Toronto]],<ref name=thestar5>{{cite news|author=Kenneth Kidd Feature Writer |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829238--tear-gas-fired-in-downtown-rampage?bn=1 |title=Tear gas fired in downtown rampage |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-27|accessdate=2010-06-27 | location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630071741/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829238--tear-gas-fired-in-downtown-rampage?bn=1| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> being deployed in a few locations by muzzle blasts. [[Rubber bullet]]s and [[pepper spray]] were also used against many protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thestar.blogs.com/g20/ |title=G20 — Toronto 2010 |publisher=Thestar.blogs.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100524115504/http://thestar.blogs.com/g20/| archivedate= 24 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/06/26/canada.g8.summit/index.html?hpt=T1 |title=G8 criticizes North Korea, Iran in final statement |publisher=CNN.com |date= 2010-06-27|accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100703154015/http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/06/26/canada.g8.summit/index.html?hpt=T1| archivedate= 3 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/protesters-turn-violent-smashing-storefront-glass-and-police-cars/article1619460/ |title=Protests turn violent: storefronts smashed, June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Several media personnel, including a Canadian reporter for ''[[The Guardian]]'', a CTV producer, and two photographers for the ''[[National Post]]'', were also arrested.<ref>{{cite news|last=Austen|first=Ian|title=Hundreds Arrested in Summit Protests in Toronto|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/28/world/americas/28security.html?src=mv|accessdate=27 Post photographers arrested at G20 protest|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2010/06/26/two-post-photographers-arrested-at-g20-protest/|accessdate=27 June 2010|newspaper=National Post|date=June 26, 2010| archiveurl= https://archive.is/20100630063940/http://news.nationalpost.com/2010/06/26/two-post-photographers-arrested-at-g20-protest/| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Condemnations of the violence were made by Ontario premier [[Dalton McGuinty]] and Toronto Mayor [[David Miller (Canadian politician)|David Miller]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/toronto-mayor-amongst-many-expressing-revulsion-over-protest-violence/article1619819/ |title=Toronto mayor amongst many expressing revulsion over protest violence |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date= 2010-06-26|accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628133121/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/toronto-mayor-amongst-many-expressing-revulsion-over-protest-violence/article1619819/| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In a press conference, Miller said, "All Torontonians should be outraged. They're criminals who came to Toronto deliberately to break the law. They are not welcome in this city."<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref name=thestar5 /> Referring to damage caused by black bloc protesters downtown, he claimed that calling the attackers protesters was "not fair to the people who came to [legally] protest,"<ref name="autogenerated3"/> and that they were in fact "criminals."<ref name=autogenerated3 /> In a statement, [[Dimitri Soudas]], spokesperson for Prime Minister Stephen Harper, proclaimed, "Free speech is a principle of our democracy, but the thugs that prompted violence earlier today represent in no way, shape or form the Canadian way of life."<ref>{{cite news|last=Update|first=Globe and Mail|title=Protesters turn violent, smash storefront glass and set police cruiser ablaze |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/protesters-turn-violent-smashing-storefront-glass-and-police-cars/article1619460/|accessdate=26 June 2010|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=June 26, 2010|location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628051746/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/protesters-turn-violent-smashing-storefront-glass-and-police-cars/article1619460/| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===June 27: Police brutality protests=== [[File:Toronto G20 Protests.tif|thumb|People boxed in by riot police at [[Queen Street West|Queen]] and [[Spadina Avenue|Spadina]]]] Approximately 480 arrestees were taken to the [[Eastern Avenue (Toronto)|Eastern Avenue]] temporary holding centre during the previous day's protests; police initially gave numbers ranging from 32 to 130. While those with minor charges or dropped charges were released, those with serious charges were set to appear in a courthouse located on [[Finch Avenue]] and [[Weston Road]] in [[North York, Ontario|North York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100627/g20-protests-100627/20100627/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto - Protesters, police clash at detention centre - CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630150900/http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100627/g20-protests-100627/20100627/?hub=TorontoNewHome| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>http://www.winnipegsun.com/news/g20/2010/06/27/14539176.html Arrests a 'catch-and-release program'</ref>
After closed services throughout the night, the following morning saw the resumption of regular TTC and GO Transit services, while G20 leaders began formal discussions at the [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]]. Lockdowns at [[University Avenue (Toronto)|University Avenue]] hospitals and the [[Toronto Eaton Centre]] were also lifted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100627/toronto_G20_shutdowns_100627/20100627/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto - TTC and GO Transit service resume - CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-06-12 |accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref> Additional officers from the [[Ontario Provincial Police]] were deployed, doubling the total number of officers to 20,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100627/more_arrests_toronto_100627/20100627/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto - Police take 'pre-emptive strikes' with sweeping arrests - CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref>
Four arrests were made during the twilight of June 27 after two security guards witnessed men emerging from a [[manhole]] on [[Queen Street West]]. The manholes were later welded shut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/canada/breakingnews/four-arrested-after-emerging-from-manhole-near-g20-summit-site-97261759.html |title=Manhole arrests near G20 security zone spotlights infrastructure vulnerability |publisher=Winnipeg Free Press |date=2010-06-27 |accessdate=2010-06-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630074428/http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/canada/breakingnews/four-arrested-after-emerging-from-manhole-near-g20-summit-site-97261759.html| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
About 100 additional arrests were made during a morning raid by [[Toronto Police Service]] at the [[University of Toronto]]. Those arrested were said to be in possession of black clothing and "weapons of opportunity" such as bricks and sharpened stakes.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829313--student-union-faces-questions-about-hosting-protesters?bn=1|title=Student union faces questions about hosting protesters|publisher=Toronto Star|date=2010-06-27|accessdate=2010-06-27 | first1=Brett | last1=Popplewell | first2=Vanessa | last2=Lu| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100701144903/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829313--student-union-faces-questions-about-hosting-protesters?bn=1| archivedate= 1 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
During the mid-morning, protesters marched from Jimmie Simpson Park on Queen Street East to the front of the Eastern Avenue temporary detention centre, where a "[[jail solidarity]]" bike rally and sit-in consisting of about 150 people occurred during the afternoon, with demonstrators urging the release of those arrested the previous day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100627/more_arrests_toronto_100627/20100627/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto - Police make hundreds of arrests, take on protesters in streets - CTV News |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref> Following several arrests during the rally, protesters began a sit-in interrupted by small muzzles of pepper spray and rubber bullets fired by police.<ref>{{cite news|title=G20 arrests continue in Toronto - Toronto faces 2nd violent day: police chief|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/06/27/g20-toronto-protest.html|accessdate=27 June 2010|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=June 27, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628142933/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/06/27/g20-toronto-protest.html| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=G20 News|first=canoe.ca|title=G20 timeline for Sunday, June 27|url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/g20/2010/06/27/14534051.html|accessdate=27 June 2010|newspaper=Toronto Sun|date=June 27, 2010}}</ref> At least 224 arrests occurred by evening.<ref name="Globeandmail">{{cite news|last=Morrow|first=Adrian|title=Police arrest 562 as Toronto G20 protests continue |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/police-arrest-562-in-toronto/article1620135/|accessdate=28 June 2010|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=June 27, 2010|author2=Jeff Gray|author3=Anna Mehler Paperny|author4=Sarah Boesveld|agency=CTVglobemedia| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630085326/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/toronto/police-arrest-562-in-toronto/article1620135/| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Another large group assembled at the intersection of Queen Street West and [[Spadina Avenue]], presumably to conduct a protest, but were immediately [[kettling|surrounded]] by heavily armed police forces.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/829642--police-defend-crowd-trap-at-queen-and-spadina |title=Police defend crowd trap at Queen and Spadina |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-29|accessdate=2010-06-29 | location=Toronto | first=Jesse | last=McLean| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100701151357/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/829642--police-defend-crowd-trap-at-queen-and-spadina| archivedate= 1 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Numerous [[wikt:bystander|bystander]]s and media personnel were also in the crowd. Several arrests were made, including several members of the media and another CTV cameraman who was briefly held and then released; police later claimed that they had found weapons at the scene, and that they suspected the presence of more [[black bloc]] protesters within the crowd.<ref name="Globeandmail"/><ref>{{cite news|last=LaFlamme|first=Lisa (CTV News)|title=Police arrest quiet protesters, members of media|url=http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100627/100627_g20_protests/20100627/?hub=CP24Home|accessdate=28 June 2010|newspaper=The Canadian Press, CP24|date=June 27, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Byrne |first=Ciara |title=G20 police move aggressively against protests, one day after chaos in Toronto |url=http://www.am1150.ca/news/14/1161596 |accessdate=28 June 2010 |newspaper=The Canadian Press, AM 1150 |date=June 27, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The blockade caused traffic diversions and the stoppage of streetcar service along Spadina Avenue. After several hours of detainment in record-breaking heavy rain, police released the remainder of the crowd during the night.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
==Aftermath==
===Post-summit protests=== A total of 1118 people were arrested in relation to the G20 summit protests,<ref name="globemailjuly2011"/> the largest mass arrests in Canadian history,<ref name="Mahoney">{{cite news|last=Mahoney|first=Jill|author2=Ann Hui|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/news/g20-related-mass-arrests-unique-in-canadian-history/article1621198/ |title=G20-related mass arrests unique in Canadian history |publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=2010-06-29|accessdate=2010-07-21|location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100728172459/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/news/g20-related-mass-arrests-unique-in-canadian-history/article1621198/| archivedate= 28 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> while nearly 800 of them were released without charge.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jesse McLean|first=and Jennifer Yang|title= Anatomy of the G20: the story from both sides of the fence|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/850809--anatomy-of-the-g20-the-story-from-both-sides-of-the-fence|accessdate=20 August 2010|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=August 20, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100822235322/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/850809--anatomy-of-the-g20-the-story-from-both-sides-of-the-fence| archivedate= 22 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The remaining 231 people remained with charges before the court while 58 of them have had their charges withdrawn or stayed.<ref>{{cite news |last=Powell |first=Betsy |title=G20 charges in 73 cases cleared |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/851987--g20-charges-in-73-cases-cleared |accessdate=25 August 2010 |newspaper=Toronto Star |date=August 25, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828090414/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/851987--g20-charges-in-73-cases-cleared |archivedate=28 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Smaller-scale, non-violent protests took place the following day, June 28, during the afternoon and evening. Nearly 1000 protesters marched to [[Toronto City Hall]] and [[Queen's Park (Toronto)|Queen's Park]] to protest the treatment of arrested individuals at the [[Eastern Avenue (Toronto)|Eastern Avenue]] holding centre and demanded the release of individuals still being detained, although police had earlier released several arrested on minor charges.<ref>{{cite news|last=Perkel|first=Colin|title=Police trampled civil liberties over G20 summit weekend, groups complain|url=http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100628/100628_police_protest/20100628/?hub=CP24Home|accessdate=29 June 2010|newspaper=The Canadian Press, CP24|date=June 28, 2010}}</ref> Large numbers of Toronto Police Service officers continued to patrol the demonstrations.<ref>http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100628/toronto-g20-anti-police-rally-100628/20100628/?hub=TorontoNewHome</ref> On June 29, a group of gay activists gathered outside a community centre where Toronto Police Service chief [[Bill Blair (police chief)|Bill Blair]] was scheduled to speak to demand his resignation for the treatment of women and homophobia within the detention centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xtra.ca/blog/national/post/2010/06/29/Pride-Toronto-Toronto-Police-cocktail-party-turns-ugly.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701213752/http://www.xtra.ca/blog/national/post/2010/06/29/Pride-Toronto-Toronto-Police-cocktail-party-turns-ugly.aspx |archivedate=2010-07-01 |df= }}</ref>
===Criticism of policing=== On December 7, 2010, Andre Marin, Ontario Ombudsman, issued a report called ''Caught in the Act'', an investigation into the legality of the ''Ontario Public Works Protection Act'', and, more specifically ''Regulation 233/10'', in Marin's words, "...known as the secret security regulation, a little known and widely misunderstood legal measure that was supposed to help the police keep the peace, but in my view wound up contributing to massive violations of civil rights."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://therealnews.com/t2/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=74&jumival=6125 | title=Toronto G20: Will Police be Held Accountable After Scathing Ombudsman's Report |date=January 22, 2010 |publisher=The Real News| accessdate= 24 January 2011 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
[[File:G-20 Toronto June 2010 (6).jpg|thumb|Police were allowed to arrest anyone within five metres of the fence who would neither leave nor identify himself.]] A group of lawyers requested court injunctions against the [[Toronto Police Service]] from using newly purchased [[Long Range Acoustic Device]]s (LRAD), also known as sound cannons, during protests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/25/g20-sound-cannon.html |title=CBC News – Toronto – Limited G20 sound cannon use approved |publisher=Cbc.ca |date= 2010-06-25|accessdate=2010-06-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100627174237/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/25/g20-sound-cannon.html| archivedate= 27 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Sound cannons have been used in previous summit protests and have the ability to produce sound at ear-piercing volumes, potentially causing [[hearing impairment]]. The [[Ontario Superior Court of Justice]] later ruled that officers can use sound cannons, with a few restrictions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100625/sound_cannon_ruling_100625/20100625/ |title=hub=TorontoNewHome |publisher=Toronto.ctv.ca |date=2010-06-03 |accessdate=2010-06-26}}</ref>
The ''[[Toronto Star]]'' reported that the [[Executive Council of Ontario]] had implemented a regulation under the provincial Public Works Protection Act on June 2 granting the ISU sweeping powers of arrest within a specific boundary during the summit;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/828367--g20-law-gives-police-sweeping-powers-to-arrest-people |title=G20 law gives police sweeping powers to arrest people |publisher=thestar.com |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2010-06-24 | location=Toronto | first=Jennifer | last=Yang| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628022808/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/828367--g20-law-gives-police-sweeping-powers-to-arrest-people| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> the rule was said to designate the security fence as a [[public works]] and, as such, allow any police officer or guard to arrest any individual failing or refusing to provide identification within five metres of the security zone. The regulation was requested by [[Toronto Police Service]] chief [[Bill Blair (police chief)|Bill Blair]] and debate in the legislature was not required. [[Order in Council|Orders in Council]] such as this one are announced in the ''Ontario Gazette'', but the next issue of that publication was to be published after the order expired on June 28, a week after the summit ended. The new law came to light after a [[York University]] graduate student, who claimed to have been simply "exploring" the security zone but who did not provide identification when confronted by police, was arrested on June 24 under the regulation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/828372 |title=Man arrested and left in wire cage under new G20 law |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-25|accessdate=2010-06-26 | location=Toronto | first=Jayme | last=Poisson| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628023319/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/828372| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He later vowed to file a lawsuit against the law once the summit ended.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/828896--first-secret-law-arrestee-plans-charter-challenge?bn=1 |title=First 'secret law' arrestee plans Charter challenge |publisher=thestar.com |date= 2010-06-25|accessdate=2010-06-26 | location=Toronto | first1=Noor | last1=Javed | first2=John | last2=Goddard| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100628143928/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/828896--first-secret-law-arrestee-plans-charter-challenge?bn=1| archivedate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Government of Ontario|Cabinet]] later confirmed that the new laws were not "special powers" and that those who were believed to have been arrested under the Public Works and Protection Act were in fact arrested under the [[Criminal Code (Canada)|Criminal Code]].<ref>{{Citation| last=Talaga| first=Tanya| last2=Benzie| first2=Robert| title=No arrests made under G20 rule change, Ontario says| newspaper=Toronto Star| date=June 29, 2010| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/830030--no-arrests-made-under-g20-rule-change-ontario-says?bn=1| accessdate=June 29, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100702011925/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/830030--no-arrests-made-under-g20-rule-change-ontario-says?bn=1| archivedate= 2 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The police chief later admitted that, despite media coverage, no such five-metre rule ever existed in the law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.ca.msn.com/top-stories/cbc-article.aspx?cp-documentid=24734479 |title=Chief admits 5-metre G20 security rule didn't exist| accessdate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
===Human rights investigations=== Individuals arrested during the protests who claimed to be [[wikt:bystander|bystander]]s not taking part in protests condemned the treatment they received from police at the [[Eastern Avenue (Toronto)|Eastern Avenue]] holding centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://niagaraatlarge.com/2010/07/05/thorold-ontario-amputee-has-his-artificial-leg-ripped-off-by-police-and-is-slammed-in-makeshift-cell-during-g20-summit-%E2%80%93-at-least-one-ontario-mpp-calls-the-whole-episode-%E2%80%9Cshocking/|title='Thorold, Ontario Amputee Has His Artificial Leg Ripped Off By Police And Is Slammed In Makeshift Cell During G20 Summit – At Least One Ontario MPP Calls The Whole Episode "Shocking"'|publisher=niagaraatlarge.com|year=2010|accessdate=2010-07-06| archiveurl= http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20130201052739/http://niagaraatlarge.com/2010/07/05/thorold-ontario-amputee-has-his-artificial-leg-ripped-off-by-police-and-is-slammed-in-makeshift-cell-during-g20-summit-%E2%80%93-at-least-one-ontario-mpp-calls-the-whole-episode-%E2%80%9Cshocking/| archivedate= 1 February 2013 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> According to testimonials given to the ''Toronto Star'' and ''[[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]]'' by a few arrestees, including university students, journalists, [[street medic]]s, teachers, tourists, photographers, and a former mayoral candidate, "[individual] rights were violated" and "police brutality [was present]." The detention centre was described as "cold" with "barely any food or water" and "no place in the cages to even sit," and "tantamount to torture." Other allegations included harassment, lack of medical care, verbal abuse, and strip searches of females by male officers.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829921--i-will-not-forget-what-they-have-done-to-me?bn=1 |title='I will not forget what they have done to me' |publisher=thestar.com |accessdate=2010-06-30 | location=Toronto |date=2010-06-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100702011919/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/829921--i-will-not-forget-what-they-have-done-to-me?bn=1| archivedate= 2 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lapresse.ca/actualites/quebec-canada/201007/01/01-4294842-soixante-heures-a-torontonamo.php |title=Soixante heures à "Torontonamo" |publisher=cyberpresse.ca |date=2010-07-02 |accessdate=2010-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberpresse.ca/opinions/201007/02/01-4295119-ma-detention-a-torontonamo.php |title=Ma détention à Torontonamo|publisher=cyberpresse.ca |date=2010-07-03 |accessdate=2010-07-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100705151328/http://www.cyberpresse.ca/opinions/201007/02/01-4295119-ma-detention-a-torontonamo.php| archivedate= 5 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> At one point, a plainclothes officer reportedly told a detainee that [[Premiership of Stephen Harper|the federal government]] had declared [[martial law]].<ref name="Walcom-STAR">{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/831443--walkom-the-g20-summit-s-grim-lessons-for-civil-liberties |title=Walkom: The G20 summit's grim lessons for civil liberties |publisher=thestar.com |accessdate=2010-07-08 | location=Toronto |date=2010-07-03| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100706004833/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/torontog20summit/article/831443--walkom-the-g20-summit-s-grim-lessons-for-civil-liberties| archivedate= 6 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Blair defended the conditions in the temporary detention centre, citing the fact that every room in the centre was under [[Closed-circuit television|video surveillance]], and that to the best of the officers' abilities, occupants were read their rights.<ref>http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100628/toronto-g20-anti-police-r,ally-100628/20100628/?hub=TorontoNewHome</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liberal.ca/en/newsroom/media-releases/18410_g8g20-billion-dollar-boondoggle-update |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626123544/http://www.liberal.ca/en/newsroom/media-releases/18410_g8g20-billion-dollar-boondoggle-update |archivedate=2010-06-26 |df= }}</ref> However, a ''Toronto Star'' commentator editorialized that "some of the elements of [[Internment camps#Internment camp|classic authoritarian detention]] were there, albeit in embryonic forms."<ref name="Walcom-STAR"/>
[[Amnesty International]] called for an official investigation into the police tactics used during the protests. The organization alleged that police violated civil liberties and used [[police brutality]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/28/g20-summitt-police-amnesty.html |title=CBC News - Toronto - Amnesty calls for summit security review |publisher=CBCnews.ca |date=2010-06-28 |accessdate=2010-06-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100629122437/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/28/g20-summitt-police-amnesty.html| archivedate= 29 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Canadian Civil Liberties Association]] decried the arrests and alleged that they occurred without "reasonable grounds to believe that everyone they detained had committed a crime."<ref>{{cite news|author=Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/news/g20-related-mass-arrests-unique-in-canadian-history/article1621198/ |title=G20-related mass arrests unique in Canadian history |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date= 2010-06-28|accessdate=2010-06-29 |location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630110823/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/g8-g20/news/g20-related-mass-arrests-unique-in-canadian-history/article1621198/| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Toronto Police Service held press conferences to speak out against inappropriate actions of protesters, including displaying items alleged to have been seized from protesters. However, when confronted, [[Bill Blair (police chief)|Chief Blair]] admitted that some of the items were unrelated to the G20 protests.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/30/g20-weapons.html | work=CBC News | title=Police accused of displaying fake G20 weapons | date=2010-06-30| accessdate= 1 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100702151836/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/06/30/g20-weapons.html| archivedate= 2 July 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Police officers were also reported to attack detained [[journalists]], while forcing other journalists to leave the scene of the protests.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/06/28/g20-rosenfeld-police.html | work=CBC News | title=Police beat journalist covering G20: report | date=2010-06-28| accessdate= 26 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
===Adam Nobody=== Protestor Adam Nobody, 27, was arrested in Queen's Park on 26 June. An amateur video uploaded to [[YouTube]]<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hym0afc03pE</ref> showed at least a dozen officers surrounding and beating Nobody, who was not armed and did not appear to resist. He suffered a broken nose and cheekbone, and was charged with assaulting police. These charges were eventually dropped, and a [[Special Investigations Unit]] investigation was opened into the incident. This investigation was closed without any charges laid, because the SIU was unable to identify the officers. They had covered their identification badges, police witnesses all claimed to be unable to identify them, and the arresting officer had written an invalid ID number on Nobody's arrest record.
Police chief Bill Blair insisted that a "forensic examination" had proven the video was "tampered with," removing proof that Nobody was an armed, violent criminal, but soon retracted this statement admitting he had no evidence to support it. Blair's claims led to increased attention to the case, new witnesses coming forward, and a second video corroborating the first. On 30 November the SIU re-opened its investigation, obtained the co-operation of a police officer who witnessed the incident, and laid charges against Const. Babak Andalib-Goortani. The SIU has the names of other officers involved but has not yet laid charges against them.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/torontog20summit/article/898432--blair-says-g20-youtube-video-was-tampered-with | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Jayme | last=Poisson | title=Blair blasts SIU over findings of 'probable' excessive force | date=2010-11-29| accessdate= 23 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/torontog20summit/article/901332--chief-blair-apologizes-to-g20-protester-at-centre-of-youtube-video | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Jayme | last=Poisson | title=Chief Blair apologizes to G20 protester at centre of YouTube video | date=2010-12-03| accessdate= 23 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/torontog20summit/article/902664 | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Rosie | last=DiManno | title=A second look at G20 police assault | date=2010-12-07| accessdate= 23 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/ontario-police-watchdog-reopens-g20-nobody-arrest-investigation/article1819175/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | first=Adrian | last=Morrow | title=Ontario police watchdog reopens G20 'Nobody' arrest investigation - The Globe and Mail | date=2010-11-30| accessdate= 23 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101201044629/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/ontario-police-watchdog-reopens-g20-nobody-arrest-investigation/article1819175/| archivedate= 1 December 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/article/910856--g20-officer-tight-lipped-at-siu-appearance | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Jayme | last=Poisson | title=G20 officer tight-lipped at SIU appearance | date=2010-12-22| accessdate= 23 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2010/12/22/charges-siu-g20.html | work=CBC News | title=SIU knows all 3 officers in alleged G20 assault | date=2010-12-22| accessdate= 23 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/how-a-man-named-nobody-became-the-battered-face-of-g20-protests/article1818432/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | first=Joe | last=Friesen | title=How a man named Nobody became the battered face of G20 protests | date=2010-11-30| accessdate= 23 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110122173321/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/toronto/how-a-man-named-nobody-became-the-battered-face-of-g20-protests/article1818432/| archivedate= 22 January 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Blair, PM Stephen Harper and the Toronto Police have been harshly criticized over the incident, with many commentators calling for Blair to resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2010/12/22/kelly-mcparland-torontos-shallow-cowardly-cops/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120708053158/http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2010/12/22/kelly-mcparland-torontos-shallow-cowardly-cops/ |archivedate=2012-07-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews%3D53938 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101223223103/http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=53938 |archivedate=2010-12-23 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.torontosun.com/news/columnists/joe_warmington/2010/12/21/16638186.html</ref>
==Investigation and charges against police==
=== Babak Andalib-Goortani === In 2013, Andalib-Goortani was convicted of assault with a weapon for his role in Nobody's beating.<ref>{{cite news|first=Alyshah |last=Hasham |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2013/09/12/g20_assault_trial_guilty_verdict_for_officer_who_hit_adam_nobody.html |title=G20 assault trial: Guilty verdict for officer who hit Adam Nobody|newspaper=Toronto Star| date= September 12, 2013|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref> The trial judge, Ontario Court Justice Louise Botham, commented that "a police officer is not entitled to use unlimited force to affect an arrest."<ref name="NtlPost2013">{{cite web |title=Toronto police officer Babak Andalib-Goortani found guilty of assault with weapon against G20 protester Adam Nobody |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/posted-toronto/toronto-police-officer-babak-andalib-goortani-found-guilty-of-assault-with-weapon-against-g20-protester-adam-nobody |date=September 12, 2013 |publisher=[[National Post]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> Botham, who was brought in to Toronto from [[Brampton, Ontario|Brampton]] to hear the case, subsequently sentenced Andalib-Goortani to 45 days in jail.<ref name="CBC2013">{{cite web |title=G20 assault: Babak Andalib-Goortani gets 45-day sentence |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/g20-assault-babak-andalib-goortani-gets-45-day-sentence-1.2456893 |date=December 9, 2013 |publisher=[[CBC News]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> In her ruling, Botham indicated that the sentence was heavy influenced by video of Andalib-Goortani, along with a number of other officers whose disciplinary charges were dismissed, punching, kneeing, kicking, and striking the victim with a baton; stating that the period of incarceration was necessary to uphold the public's faith in the justice system.<ref name="CBC2013"/>
Less than 10 minutes after Botham announced the sentence in her Brampton courtroom, a Toronto court granted bail to Andalib-Goortani pending appeal.<ref name="Sun2013">{{cite web |author=Shawn Jeffords |title=Toronto cop sentenced to 45 days in jail for Adam Nobody assault |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2013/12/09/toronto-cop-gets-45-days-in-jail-for-adam-nobody-assault |date=December 9, 2013 |publisher=[[Toronto Sun]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> While Andalib-Goortani awaited appeal of that assault conviction, another assault with a weapon charge, for a G20 attack on journalist/blogger Wyndham {{nowrap|Bettencourt-McCarthy}}, was thrown out when the photograph taken a she was about to be hit with the baton, showing a riot-geared officer which another officer was ready to testify was Andalib-Goortani, was ruled inadmissible because the photo had been obtained through an anonymous website posting and the photographer could not be called to testify.<ref>{{cite web |author=Colin Perkel, The Canadian Press |title=Babak Andalib-Goortani, G20 Cop, Acquitted On 2nd Assault Charge |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/09/24/babak-andalib-goortani_n_5875964.html |date=September 24, 2014 |publisher=[[Huffington Post]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Sarah Sweet |title=Cop Acquitted on Charge of Assaulting Former ''Torontoist'' Contributor at G20 Protests — {{resize|Photographic evidence ruled inadmissible.}} |url=http://torontoist.com/2014/09/cop-acquitted-on-charge-of-assaulting-former-torontist-contributor-at-g20-protests/ |date=September 24, 2014 |publisher=[[Torontoist]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Babak Andalib-Goortani acquitted in 2nd G20 incident |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/babak-andalib-goortani-acquitted-in-2nd-g20-incident-1.2776735 |date=September 24, 2014 |publisher=[[CBC News]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref>
Some 16 months after being sentenced to jail time and released on bail, Toronto Superior Court Justice Brian O'Marra overturned the sentence and, without providing reasons for his decision, instead ordered that Andalib-Goortani do 75 hours of community service with one year's probation.<ref>{{cite web |author=Alyshah Hasham |title=No jail for Toronto police officer convicted of G20 assault |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2015/01/29/no-jail-for-toronto-police-officer-convicted-of-g20-assault.html |date=January 29, 2015 |publisher=[[Toronto Star]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Judge lightens sentence of officer convicted of assaulting G20 protester |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/g20-officers-conviction-stands-but-he-need-not-serve-jail-time-judge-rules/article22697292/ |date=January 29, 2015 |publisher=[[The Globe and Mail]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> In November 2015, retired Toronto judge Lee Ferrier, presiding over the Toronto Police Service's disciplinary hearing of Andalib-Goortani, docked Andalib-Goortani five days pay for the incident, thus returning the officer to patrol the streets of Toronto.<ref>{{cite web |author=Rosie DiManno |title=Retired judge all but weeps for guilty G20 cop: DiManno |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2015/11/11/retired-judge-all-but-weeps-for-guilty-g20-cop-dimanno.html |date=November 11, 2015 |publisher=[[Toronto Star]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref>
=== David 'Mark' Fenton === In 2014, Toronto Police Superintendent Mark Fenton, was charged with unlawful arrest and discreditable conduct in relation to the [[kettling]] incidents and faced a disciplinary hearing.<ref>{{cite web |author=Wendy Gillis |title='Toronto deteriorated into a sense of lawlessness,' says G20 police commander |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2014/12/17/the_city_of_toronto_deteriorated_says_g20_police_commander_charged_with_misconduct.html |date=December 17, 2014 |publisher=[[Toronto Star]]}}</ref> Fenton was one of two major incident commanders, in charge of the Major Incident Command Centre during the summit, and was the one on duty when he ordered the kettling of protestors both at the Novotel on the Esplanade and at Queen and Spadina.<ref>{{cite web |author=Colin Perkel |title=Misconduct case for Toronto police officer in G20 'kettling' put over |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/misconduct-case-for-toronto-police-officer-in-g20-kettling-put-over/article7035463/ |date=January 8, 2013 |publisher=[[The Globe and Mail]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref>
On August 25, 2015, more than five years after the Toronto G20 incidents leading to the charges, Fenton was found guilty of two counts of unlawful arrest and one count of discreditable conduct, disciplinary charges under the [[Police Services Act of Ontario|''Police Act'']], in relation to the "kettling" of protestors and passers-by at the intersection of Queen Street and Spadina Avenue and at the Novotel hotel on the Esplanade.<ref>{{cite web |author=Wendy Gillis |title=G20 commander apologizes after being convicted of misconduct |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2015/08/25/toronto-police-g20-supervisor-found-guilty-of-misconduct.html |date=August 25, 2015 |publisher=[[Toronto Star]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> In rendering judgment, retired Ontario judge John Hamilton explained that "Legitimate protesters … had the right not to be subject to arrest for making noise, chanting and sitting in the public street.".<ref>{{cite web |author=Cara McKenna, The Canadian Press |title=More than five years later, senior officer found guilty over mass arrests, ‘kettling’ at 2010 G20 protests |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/toronto-g20-officer-david-fenton-charged |date=August 25, 2015 |publisher=[[National Post]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> Hamilton indicated that he believed Fenton was committed to serving the public, but that he did not properly understand the constitutional right of the public to protest.<ref name="CP24"/> In addition to the unlawful arrest convictions, Hamilton deemed Fenton guilty of discreditable conduct resultant from keeping people corralled in the streets during a severe thunderstorm while his duty was to protect them from such harsh weather; however he found him not guilty of the same charge in relation to the Novotel because those unlawfully arrested did not suffer similar hardships.<ref name="CP24">{{cite web |author=Cara McKenna, The Canadian Press |title=T.O. cop found guilty on 3 charges stemming from G20 protests |url=http://www.cp24.com/news/t-o-cop-found-guilty-on-3-charges-stemming-from-g20-protests-1.2531835 |date=August 25, 2015 |publisher=[[CP24]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> Fenton was found not guilty on charges of unnecessary exercise of authority relating to the treatment of protestors after they were arrested and taken away because another officer of equal rank was in charge of the Prisoner Processing Centre; that officer was never charged.<ref>{{cite web |title=Senior police officer found guilty of 3 charges in G20 disciplinary hearing |url=http://www.reddeeradvocate.com/news/Senior_police_officer_found_guilty_of_3_charges_in_G20_disciplinary_hearing_322858231.html |date=August 25, 2015 |publisher=[[Red Deer Advocate]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref>
The sentencing hearing is expected to begin December 21, 2015 with penalty possibilities ranging from reprimand to dismissal.<ref>{{cite web |author=Michele Mandel, [[Toronto Sun]] |title=Senior G20 cop guilty on three charges |url=http://www.ottawasun.com/2015/08/25/judgment-day-for-senior-g20-cop |date=August 25, 2015 |publisher=[[Ottawa Sun]] |accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> Sentencing concluded on 15 June 2016. Regarding count one (the Novotel Misconduct) Fenton was given a formal reprimand. Regarding count two (the Queen and Spadina Misconduct) Fenton was sentenced to the forfeiture of 10 vacation days. Regarding count three (the Queen and Spadina Discreditable Conduct) Fenton was sentenced to the forfeiture of 20 vacation days.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ccla.org/cclanewsite/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Fenton-Penalty-Decision_June-15-2016-C1631822xA0E3A.pdf|title=Fenton Penalty Decision|last=Hamilton|first=John|date=June 15, 2016|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
